column1: Haderslev (Danish pronunciation: [ˈhæðˀɐˌsle̝w]; German: Hadersleben ) is a Danish town in the Region of Southern Denmark with a population of 22
column2: 101 (1 January 2020). It is the main town and the administrative seat of Haderslev Municipality and is situated in the eastern part of Southern Jutland. Haderslev is home of Sønderjyske
column3: which is an association football team that plays in the Danish Superliga for the 2018-19 season. The town is named after King Hader.

column1: == History ==
=== Overview ===
Haderslev is situated in a valley
column2: leading from Vojens to Haderslev Fjord and the Baltic Sea.

column1: Haderslev was presumably founded by Vikings at least a century before it was granted status as royal borough in 1292. At that time
column2: it had become one of the main trading centres in Southern Jutland.

column1: In the 16th century
column2: the city became one of the first Scandinavian centres of Lutheranism during the Reformation. Prior to the Second Schleswig War of 1864
column3: Haderslev was situated in the Duchy of Schleswig
column5: so its history is properly included in the contentious history of Schleswig-Holstein. From 1864 it was part of Prussia
column6: and as such part of the North German Confederation
column8: part of the German Empire. In the 1920 Schleswig Plebiscite that returned Northern Schleswig to Denmark
column9: 38.6% of Haderslev's inhabitants voted for remaining part of Germany and 61.4% voted for the cession to Denmark. It was formerly the capital of the German Kreis Hadersleben and the Danish Haderslev County.

column2: which has existed since the middle of the 13th century
column3: and since 1922 it was the seat of Haderslev Diocese. The town was an important breeding ground for the reformation in Denmark
column4: and as early as 1526 Christian introduced

column1: Another noticeable church is the white-chalked Sankt Severin Church

column1: Because of a renovation of the town's oldest houses
column2: it means Haderslev offers a unique collection of houses and buildings from 1400 to the beginning of the 20th century

column1: === Festival ===
In the public park "Kløften"
column2: near the town's center
column3: Kløften Festival is held - a three-day annual festival in the summer. The festival uses one of Haderslev's important trademarks
column4: the red-bricked water tower near the park as its logo.

column1: === Education in Haderslev ===
Three branches of University College South (Danish: University College Syd) can be found in Haderslev.
=== Former municipality (1970–2006) ===
A kommune by the previous name existed 1970–2006. It belonged to South Jutland County and covered an area of 272 square kilometres (105 sq mi) with a total population of 56
column2: 116 (2011). Its last mayor was Hans Peter Geil
column3: a member of the liberal (Venstre) political party.

column2: Vojens to the west
column4: and Assens (on the island of Funen) to the East.
